channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: It’s Been a Chilling Week for Free Speech in America
item.description: Trump’s attacks hit a “new low,” the head of the Committee to Protect Journalists said.

item.title: Trump Presents Ukraine With a ‘Very Tough Choice’
item.description: Zelensky said he’s being asked to decide between Ukraine losing its dignity or losing a key partner.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Are Both Struggling to Finance Their War
item.description: Moscow’s situation is better, but new sanctions could do serious damage.

item.title: COP30 Seeks to Tackle Climate Change but Won’t Go After Its Source
item.description: A revised draft agreement omits any mention of fossil fuels, the leading cause of global warming.

item.title: How Solar Energy Could Transform Geopolitics
item.description: Environmentalist Bill McKibben on the incredible growth of clean energy in 2025.

item.title: Foreign-Policy Fantasy Literature
item.description: Under Trump 2.0, a new book by policymaking heavyweights is an exercise in absurdity.

item.title: How Yesterday’s Fiction Foretells Tomorrow’s Politics
item.description: From medieval Europe to the Trump era, life really does imitate art.

item.title: America has dumped a messy, sordid “peace plan” on Ukraine
item.description: Volodymyr Zelensky has no choice but to play along and try to improve it

item.title: How a ‘Fairy-Tale Country’ for Women Turned Its Back on Feminism
item.description: Julia Ioffe’s new feminist history of Russia offers important lessons for the West.

item.title: The French New Wave Is Still New
item.description: Richard Linklater’s “Nouvelle Vague” shows how we’re still catching our breath from “Breathless.”

item.title: A New Opening for a Fossil-Fuel Phaseout?
item.description: For too long, climate diplomacy has dodged the politically explosive question of using fossil-fuel revenues to support the clean-energy transition. Brazil has confronted the issue head-on, using COP30 to force producer countries to face the economic and political necessity of a planned and just diversification strategy.

item.title: Erik Prince, America’s most notorious mercenary, spies opportunity in chaos
item.description: The return of the Blackwater founder is a sign of the times

item.title: The U.N.’s Latest Haiti Mandate Is a Rebrand, Not a Rethink
item.description: The Gang Suppression Force repackages the same strategies that have failed the country for decades.

item.title: Why Bihar’s Election Wasn’t a ‘Win’ for Women in Democracy
item.description: Yes, women had jaw-dropping voter turnout – but that shouldn’t obscure the dismally low number of female candidates.

item.title: How to Respond to Chinese Imports
item.description: China’s export machine demands the attention of economic policymakers everywhere. But erecting trade barriers is the wrong response and distracts from the need for more targeted measures to address the risks to national security, innovation, and jobs.

item.title: Documenting War Crimes in Sudan Begins Now
item.description: Stopping ongoing violence in conflict zones is urgent, but with today’s technology, so is gathering evidence.

item.title: China’s AI Push in the Gulf Region
item.description: Chinese AI companies are changing the nature of China’s influence in Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Qatar.

item.title: How China Is Using Brazil to Reshape Power in the Americas
item.description: China is entrenching itself in the Brazilian industrial base and consumer economy, with implications for Chinese influence across the continent.

item.title: Why Did India’s China-Related Concerns Not Figure on the Agenda of the Colombo Security Conclave in Delhi?
item.description: Most of the grouping’s member-states have good relations with Beijing. India does not want to irk them in any way.

item.title: Is Politics Dead in Kyrgyzstan?
item.description: As snap parliamentary elections approach, there’s a distinct lack of energy or interest.

item.title: America’s Asia Strategy Has an HBCU Problem
item.description: The underrepresentation of Black Americans in U.S.-Asia relations carries strategic consequences for America’s future in the Indo-Pacific.

item.title: Stablecoins Are Inevitable
item.description: While financial innovations often emerge on the system’s periphery, beyond the reach of regulation, if they prove to be systemically important, they end up being integrated into the system’s regulated core. Stablecoins are likely to follow this trajectory.

item.title: Takaichi’s Growth Gamble: The 30-Year JGB Is Flashing a Warning
item.description: Japan’s resilience, despite the world’s highest public debt ratio, stems from its debt structure. But the conditions undergirding that structure are changing.

item.title: You Should Be Reading This on TikTok
item.description: Why Washington’s foreign-policy community needs to take its conversation to a new platform.

item.title: China Will Help Rebuild Ukraine – But That Comes With Risks
item.description: Other examples of European countries beholden to Chinese funding carry a cautionary tale.

item.title: China’s Fujian: A Milestone, Not the Endpoint, of Naval Modernization
item.description: Advanced EMALS technology and a next-generation air wing position Beijing for far-reaching maritime influence — but major operational challenges remain.

item.title: How Democracies Learn to Goose-Step
item.description: Democracies rarely collapse in a single blow. The shift toward authoritarianism often unfolds through a series of small, seemingly trivial steps that become consequential once social pressures push citizens to fall in line.

item.title: Latin America’s Ascendant Right Is Tested at the Ballot Box
item.description: Weekend elections in Chile and Ecuador offer a snapshot of a regional trend.

item.title: Should adults take colostrum supplements?
item.description: Claims for “first milk” have been exaggerated, but trials point to some benefits

item.title: Inside China’s Rare Earth Empire: The Hidden Costs in Myanmar
item.description: Welcome to the dirty side of rare earths, which ironically are key to the “clean energy” transition.

item.title: The Right Way to Rebuild Gaza’s Health System
item.description: Palestinians are already leading efforts to rebuild the health system in Gaza. The question now is whether the international community will support them by delivering emergency assistance – such as restoring access to fuel, water, and medical supplies – in ways that strengthen local institutions and governance.

item.title: Trump’s Dreadful Peace Plan for Ukraine
item.description: The White House is giving Putin permission to try again.

item.title: Philippines’ Pig Butchering Poster Girl Gets Life in Prison
item.description: Onetime small town mayor Alice Guo sentenced under anti-trafficking laws.

item.title: The G20 Must Help Africa Escape the Financial Death Trap
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s tariff war has hindered progress on sustainable development in African countries – a process that has long been stymied by global inequalities. To address this issue, the G20 must maintain the momentum of South Africa’s presidency and push for a much-needed overhaul of international trade and finance.

item.title: Battle of History: China, Taiwan and the October 25th Clash
item.description: Beijing is looking for an opportunity to exploit differing views of history.

item.title: China’s Fourth Plenum and the 2027 Problem
Will the AI Boom Continue?
item.description: Amid growing concerns about an AI bubble, Nvidia’s stellar third-quarter earnings report has reinvigorated faith in the industry and the opportunities the technology represents. But as the money pours in, the risks to jobs, governance, and the planet continue to mount.

item.title: The Big Picture
UAE’s AI ambitions advance
item.description:
Microsoft, a US firm, announced on November 3rd that the US…

The post UAE’s AI ambitions advance appeared first on Economist Intelligence Unit.

item.title: China EV sales to slow from 2026
item.description:
Electric vehicles (EVs) now account for around half of the…

The post China EV sales to slow from 2026 appeared first on Economist Intelligence Unit.

item.title: Corruption and Climate Crisis a Deadly Combination in the Philippines
item.description: The impact of natural disasters has been exacerbated by widespread corruption in government infrastructure, including flood control projects.

item.title: The Peril of Ousting Maduro
item.description: Only a gradual transition—not regime change by corce—can restore Venezuela’s democracy.

item.title: US Congressional Panel Proposes Taiwanese Role in Funding Philippine Base Upgrades
item.description: The suggestion by the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission is unlikely to go down well in Beijing – or Manila.
